title: Working with Branches
subtitle: Create Parallel Universes for Your Code
description:
# Understanding Branches Imagine you're writing a book. You want to try a different ending, but you don't want to delete what you already wrote. You could: - Make a copy of the entire book - Try the new ending in the copy - If you like it, use it; if not, keep the original **That's what branches do in Git!** ## What is a Branch? A branch is a separate line of development. It lets you: - üß™ **Experiment** without affecting the main code - üî® **Develop features** in isolation - üêõ **Fix bugs** on a separate timeline - ü§ù **Collaborate** without stepping on each other's toes ## The Main Branch Every Git repository starts with a default branch, usually called: - `main` (modern convention) - `master` (older convention) This is your "official" or "production" code. ## Creating and Switching Branches ```bash # Create a new branch git branch feature-login # Switch to a branch git checkout feature-login # Create AND switch in one command (modern way) git checkout -b feature-login # Or with newer Git versions git switch -c feature-login ``` ## Viewing Branches ```bash # List all branches (* shows current branch) git branch # List with more details git branch -v ``` ## Example Workflow ```bash # Check current branch git branch # Create and switch to new feature branch git checkout -b add-homepage # Make changes, stage, and commit echo "

Welcome

" > index.html git add index.html git commit -m "Add homepage" # Switch back to main git checkout main ``` ## Your Quest You're about to add a new feature to your project. Write Git commands to: 1. Create a new branch called `new-feature` 2. Switch to that branch Use the modern one-command approach with `git checkout -b`.
